For the full grant to be given to each authority, it is assumed that expenditure will increase by no more than 5·25 per cent. That is still above the rate of inflation—now running at about 4·5 per cent.—and the addition for teachers' pay means that local authorities' expenditure can go up by 7·75 per cent. on average without loss of the full grant from the Government.
Opposition Members have mentioned what local authorities may not get, but authorities will lose money only if they overspend; so it is up to them whether they get grants or not. If they go over the top, they will forfeit them. If they have to hand the money back, that is on their heads. We do not claw it back intentionally.
I shall give Opposition Members a tip to pass on to their overspending councils. If they can cut the increase in their expenditure to 4·5 per cent., they will get £100 million more. We should be delighted to see such financial sobriety. The hon. Member for Copeland (Dr. Cunningham) mentioned a figure of £400 million that
appears in the Red Book. I have looked for it there and have not been able to find it. Perhaps we can meet afterwards with an umpire to discuss the matter.

The hon. Member for Copeland claimed that the Government expected rate rises from the Exchequer that were significantly higher than the 6 per cent. that was quoted by my right hon. Friend the Secretary of State. I have tracked down the reconciliation of 8·5 per cent. and 6 per cent. in order to put the hon. Gentleman right, because what he said was erroneous.
The reconciliation with the 6 per cent. increase in rate poundage is as follows. Of the 2·5 per cent difference, over 1 per cent. represents buoyancy in rateable values; 0·5 per cent. represents the fact that we are talking about England alone, and rate rises in Scotland are unfortunately even higher; another 0·5 per cent. is because we now have better information; the final 0·5 per cent is—[Interruption.] Right enough: hon. Members do not like it now that we are putting the figures right. They can throw figures across, but they do not like it when they are thrown back. But there the actual figures are and they are perfectly clear. We can have a look at it together afterwards. The offer is on the floor ready to be picked up. How much more generous could I be?
One should also put on the record regarding the rate support grant the difference of increase between Conservative and Labour and Liberal authorities, as my right hon. Friend did. These figures are up to midday today, so they could not be more up to date. Conservative authorities as a whole are spending 7·5 per cent. more and are levying a rate of 5·4 per cent. more. Labour authorities not rate-capped are spending 9·6 per cent. more, which is 2 per cent. more than Conservative authorities, and they are levying rates of 12·4 per cent. More—7 per cent. on average more than Conservative authorities. In hung councils they are spending 9·4 per cent. more and levying 7 per cent. more.

I will give way in a minute. I must just give these figures in case I forget them, and I would not like to deprive the House.
Among the shires, the Conservative authorities are spending 6·5 per cent. more and the Labour authorities are spending 8·7 per cent. more. Among London boroughs which are not rate-capped, in Conservative boroughs the increase in rates is 4·6 per cent. only. The increase in nonrate-capped Labour boroughs in London is 60·6 per cent.—15 times more. If the electorate wants to know what a Labour Government would be like, there it is.
Reference has been made to the three London boroughs, and I shall mention them again. I know that Opposition Members do not like them mentioned. [Interruption.] I am glad to hear that they do not mind; we can tell the electors that.

Is my hon. Friend aware that Lancashire county council has shot away with rates every years since it took office? This year, with the assistance of the Liberals, the rate has doubled. [AN HON. MEMBER: "Niggers in the woodpile."] The Conservative-controlled city councils kept their rates absolutely level and the Wyre borough council's rate was barely in concert with the cost of living. So we are streets ahead of Labour and the Liberals.

There comes the voice of confidence from the Conservative Benches. We heard the silence from the Opposition Benches as those figures were given.
I should like to mention again the three boroughs, as a warning to the country. The increase in the local rate in Hammersmith and Fulham is 127 per cent. My hon. Friends the Members for Ealing, North (Mr. Greenway) and for Ealing, Acton (Sir G. Young) have both talked this evening about the increase in Ealing and I believe that my hon. Friend the Member for Ealing, North was absent for only a short while because residents of Ealing were coming to see him about this increase. The increase there is 72 per cent. In Waltham Forest the increase is 67 per cent.
The only reason that Brent has not increased similarly, when it went from basically Conservative and Liberal support to Labour this year, is the fact that it is rate-capped. I know that many people in the three other boroughs will wish that they were rate-capped as well. As hon. Members know, rate capping is on the basis of budgeted spending for the previous year in relation to GRE, not on the rate increase for the year itself.
Indeed, 40 local authorities which are subject to rate capping and precept limitation for this coming year were responsible last year for 90 per cent. of the overspending the length and breadth of Britain. If that is not a defence of rate capping, I do not know what is.
Time and time again Opposition Members have referred to a north-south divide, as though money were being kept in the so-called prosperous areas of the south and even being dragged away from the north. Let us look at the figures.
Each year, about £1 billion in grant moves from the south-east and London to the north—the north-west, Yorkshire and Humberside. I am not grumbling about that, but that figure should be put on the record. Labour Members have bleeding hearts, as though Conservative Members were hard-faced and taking money from the north. That is not the case. Every year £1 billion goes up there.
This year, 1987–88, out of the increased expenditure this year, added to last year's figure, the north will receive £375 million in grant from the Government, compared with £150 million for the south. Two and a half times more will go to the north than to the south. That should be put on the record.
Total expenditure on urban programmes has increased from £140 million from 1978–79 to £531 million in 1987–88 —a real increase of 131 per cent. since the Government took office.
Fifty-seven authorities now produce inner-area programmes, compared with 24 when the Government took office in 1979. Since 1979, £2·2 billion in resources has been redistributed through the urban programme. More than £2 billion of private finance has also been brought in, because that Government money has been a leader that has helped things along the way. Those figures are important and should be respected. About £1 billion is switched to Merseyside every year by various grants.

The hon. Gentleman knows that that aid to the urban areas is dwarfed by the £18,000 million cut in rate support grant since 1979. The Minister talks about so-called overspending by Labour authorities and blames them because that has gone against Government spending plans. However, will he consider the point that I have put
to him? Is he in favour of the fact that that overspending has led to an increase in spending per pupil in schools, or is he against that?
The Government give money and local authorities should establish the priorities. Ealing is a good example of what such priorities can be.
Will the hon. Gentleman give way?

No, I shall not give way. I have been asked two questions and I have now forgotten one of them. Hard luck—that has gone. I acted genuinely and one answer will have to be the Opposition's lot.
Now that the hon. Gentleman has brought my attention to Ealing, let us see where the expenditure has gone. I would have forgotten about it if it had not been for his help. Expenditure in Ealing on the police co-ordinator will be £18,000 a year. A new office block to house 1,100 more staff will cost £20,000 a week. [Interruption.] I know that that is difficult to take in, but my hon. Friend the Member for Rugby and Kenilworth (Mr. Pawsey) should try. A teacher in each school paid to rid bookshelves of sexist or heterosexist material will cost £139,000. One could go on.
I shall not give way.
Order.

No, I shall not give way. The hon. Member for Blackburn has already had two minutes more than me. I gave way to the hon. Gentleman and to my hon. Friend the Member for Lancaster (Mrs. Kellett-Bowman).
A Labour councillor from a neighbouring borough, hired as a personal assistant to the Labour authority, will cost £40,000 a year.
Will the Minister give way?
I shall give way for one question only.

I am extremely grateful to the Minister for giving way. He is discussing additional spending in Ealing and I can do better than him with regard to the totals. Does he support the additional spending in Ealing of £500,000 on extra care for the elderly? Does he support the additional spending on education in Ealing? [Interruption.] Does he support the additional expenditure on recreation and sports facilities in Ealing? Does he support the additional expenditure on housing for the elderly?

The figures quoted by the hon. Member for Copeland represent a minute amount of the 65 per cent. increase in the rates. If that is the only point that the Opposition can make, they are in a bad way.
Other hon. Members have asked questions and they expect replies. The so-called "Bromley error" has been referred to by hon. Members from both sides of the House. I would like to put on record what the position is regarding that matter, as I am aware of the concern that is felt by many hon. Friends about this matter.
Due to an error, Bromley and certain other boroughs did not receive their due money for the necessary
maintenance of the roads that they had inherited from 1986 after the abolition of the GLC. That grant should have been worked out on the kilometre distance of the roads and the usage of the roads. However, certain costs were not worked out properly. My right hon. Friend attempted to correct the error in the first 1986–87 supplementary report by adjusting the multipliers. He was then challenged on a question of law, not on a question of equity.
That should be made clear, because I believe that, in the ultimate, the test of equity is important in the preservation of good society. My right hon. Friend was not challenged on equity, but on law as to whether he could use the multipliers in that way. The court decided in favour of Greenwich. The hon. Member for Copeland asked why the Government are appealing while, at the same time—
If I may just finish this point.
Abolish the court.

We did not say anything about abolishing the court—that idea is usually proposed by the Left. One can see how easily the Left consider the idea of abolishing the courts and the rule of law.
We rightly went to the Court of Appeal, but meanwhile, as a law-abiding Government — I trust that the hon. Member for Copeland would have done the same—we adjusted the figure this year. At the same time, we hoped that we would win on the appeal so that in a supplementary report, after consultation, we could rectify the inequity which existed.
My right hon. Friend the Member for Castle Point (Sir. B. Braine) asked what would happen if the Court of Appeal's judgment was in favour of the Government. Once that happens, we will consult—

I will give way when I finish. But let us get to the loud amen before we start the next hymn.
If we win in the Court of Appeal, we will consult as quickly as we can and then make an adjustment in a supplementary report. If we do not succeed in the appeal, we shall have to reassess the situation.
The Government believe that that issue also involves a question of equity as well as law. Eventually, we hope that the law is returned—as we trust that it will be by the Court of Appeal — to an equitable basis so that those for whom money was intended shall have that money rather than the other authorities which were not intended to have that money. I am aware that the main losing authorities were Bromley, £3·1 million; Barnet, £2·7 million; Essex, £2·4 million; Hillingdon, £2·3 million; Kingston, £1·4 million; Sutton, £1·3 million; and Bexley, £1 million.

I am grateful to my hon. Friend for giving way. First of all, may I correct him? The amount involved for Hillingdon is £4·6 million—£2·3 million this year and £2·3 million next year. As a result of the mess-up and incompetence in my hon. Friend's Department—[Interruption.] — wait for it — and the dishonesty of Greenwich, my local authority has lost £4·6 million. What guarantee can my hon. Friend give me that my local authority will not lose out in the long run because of that?
Answer that!

I shall answer, and the Opposition may listen if they are quiet.
I have already discussed the matter over lunch with my hon. Friend. He is to see my right hon. Friend the Secretary of State and myself tomorrow. We shall obviously continue the discussion in private. We do not want to delay the matter in any way.
Will the Minister have dinner with me? [Interruption.]

I am referring only to roads in London. I do not think that the hon. Gentleman's offer is on the menu at present.
Let me refer to the community charge. [HON. MEMBERS: "Ah!"] I am delighted to refer to it. I find it astonishing that some people were amazed when they saw the figures. They show the impact of the community charge. They have been available for some time. They are in no way secret. The Government have nothing to hide.
Journalists from various regions visited the Department on Monday. They were given figures that they could have acquired from hooks on Monday. As we had given them the figures, I felt that the least we could do was to send hon. Members of all parties — including the Liberals and the SDP—copies of what we had given the regional journalists. It seemed to me to be the way that hon. Members should he treated. There was amazement. Anybody with a ready reckoner, and knowledge of the current population level of any area and the domestic rate could work out the whole matter in three hours. Indeed, the figures are already shown in three books, two of which are in the Library. First, there is "Paying for Local Government".
I have a copy.

I am glad that the hon. Gentleman is catching up at last. He is fortunate to know me. It is a great advantage.
The other book is "The Community Charge—The Effects on English Local Authorities" by John Gibson. I do not get a commission for this. There is also a book by the Institute of Fiscal Studies. Yet there is amazement when we provide the figures. One wonders how the Opposition's Budget figures are worked out.
Community charge figures have been published separately. Hon. Members should watch for the dates. In May 1986, CIPFA published its figures, which is, as far as I know, ten months back, the Institute of Fiscal Studies published figures in March 1986—even further back—and the Institute of Local Government Studies published figures also in March 1986. Copies of the publications exist in the Library of the House. Although none of the organisations has the figures quite right, it is quite clear that anybody who was interested could have gained a reasonably accurate idea of the impact of the Government's proposals in different parts of the country at any time.
I make another offer to Opposition Members. We are quite willing to make available our estimates for the level of the community charge in each local authority area. Last year, the Department passed on 1984–85 figures in response to a request from the Association of Metropolitan Authorities. We are happy to provide 1985–86 figures to any hon. Member who wants them. The service that we provide is amazing. It is famous on both sides of the House. We are not even a private enterprise.
It is our intention shortly to place in the Library a complete set of community charge figures for 1986–87. The whole basis of the community charge on the universal business rate is based on a certain political view. We believe that businesses are moving around the country, not to where they should geographically be positioned, but to where the lowest rates are. That is one reason businesses are leaving the north and going to the south. Undoubtedly, business rates in the north are far higher than they are in the south. If we are to link the north-south divide—as a northerner who lives in the south, I shall like that —that is one of the best ways to do it. That is why we have the universal business rate.
The community charge is to make sure that all people voting, even if it is on the rebate, are doing — [Interruption.] We said about 20 per cent. It has not been fixed. I shall give a figure. The whole basis of the system is that voters should pay something towards the services that they receive. They should not just be voting to spend other people's money.
I believe that that is right and that this is a good settlement. I am glad that I have been able to give information to the Opposition that they will be able to study through the night.
The House divided: Ayes 314, Noes 173.
